title: Back to basics: A systems thinker's view on circularity - GreenBiz
summary: The circular economy is a systems approach to sustainability, focusing on cycling resources, reducing waste and pollution, and regenerating nature. It differs from sustainability, which generally aims to reduce impacts on people and the planet as compared to the status quo. Circularity must sit at the core of operations, aiming for profitability while simultaneously addressing global issues such as pollution, nature and biodiversity loss, and climate change.

green_product: FALSE. The article does not describe a specific green product.

title: Pathways towards circular plastics in Europe — good practice examples from countries, business and citizens - European Environment Agency
summary: This article presents a three-pronged pathway for achieving a sustainable and circular plastics system: smarter use, increased circularity, and the use of renewable materials. The article highlights several good practice examples for each pathway, including initiatives by businesses, policymakers, and citizens. The examples demonstrate how to reduce the production of new plastics, increase the intensity and efficiency of use of plastics, and improve the collection, sorting, and recycling of plastics.

title: What is zero waste? - World Economic Forum
summary: Zero waste is a way of reducing waste sent to landfills and the environment by refusing excess items, reducing consumption, reusing and repairing old items, and recycling and composting any waste that cannot be reused. Many major organizations endorse zero waste practices, and many cities have zero waste goals, such as San Francisco, Portland, and New York City. Zero waste actions can reduce methane emissions, improve sustainability, save the planet's resources, and boost local economies by supporting refill shops, recycling, and composting.
green_innovation: TRUE. Zero waste is an innovation that reduces negative environmental externalities by reducing waste, conserving resources, and reducing harmful substances during production and waste disposal.
business_innovation: TRUE. Zero waste is a new and improved business process that differs significantly from previous business practices and can be associated with digital technologies for greater efficacy, resource efficiency, affordability, convenience, and usability.
green_product: TRUE. Zero waste is a green product because it is designed, manufactured, and used in a way that significantly reduces its environmental impact throughout its life cycle, emphasizing the use of environmentally benign materials, sustainable production processes, and product functionalities that support recycling and low environmental impact during usage and disposal.
green_process: TRUE. Zero waste is a green process because it is a set of methods or techniques in manufacturing, production, or any other operational activity that minimizes environmental impacts and promotes sustainability. Zero waste processes aim to reduce waste, conserve natural resources, decrease energy consumption, and limit the release of harmful substances into the environment.

greenwashing: FALSE. This article describes innovations that reduce waste and pollution, and does not use language typical of greenwashing.

summary: The circular economy, a model that prioritizes reusing, recycling, and sharing products, can reduce greenhouse gas emissions by 39%. Startups can create green innovations that are affordable and accessible, such as refurbished technology and rental equipment, and they can also offer waste management solutions that help to reduce plastic pollution.

title: Innovating for a circular world - Huhtamaki
summary: Huhtamaki, a sustainable packaging solutions company, has made significant strides in green innovation and circular economy initiatives in 2022. Key highlights include the launch of a home compostable paper-based coffee capsule in collaboration with Nespresso, a 100% recyclable mono-material blister packaging solution, and the establishment of The Cup Collective, an industrial-scale paper cup recycling initiative in Europe. These innovations aim to reduce environmental impact, promote sustainable practices, and drive circularity across the value chain.

title: Vestas unveils circularity solution to end landfill for turbine blades - Vestas
summary: Vestas has developed a new solution to make epoxy-based wind turbine blades circular, without the need to change the design or composition of the blade material. This solution involves a novel chemical process that can break down epoxy resin into virgin-grade materials, and it is expected to eliminate the need for blade redesign or landfill disposal for epoxy-based blades when they are decommissioned. Vestas has partnered with Olin and Stena Recycling to scale up the new chemical disassembly process into a commercial solution. Once mature, the solution will signal the beginning of a circular economy for all existing and future epoxy-based turbine blades.
green_innovation: TRUE. The new chemical process developed by Vestas and its partners is a green innovation because it contributes to the environmental sustainability goal of reducing resource consumption by developing a circular economy.
business_innovation: TRUE. The new chemical process developed by Vestas and its partners is a business innovation because it is a new and improved business process for one or more business functions that differs significantly from the firm’s previous business processes and that has been brought into use in the firm.
green_product: TRUE. The new chemical process developed by Vestas and its partners can be used to create new turbine blades made from re-used blade material. This will reduce the need for raw materials and reduce the environmental impact of blade manufacturing.
green_process: TRUE. The new chemical process developed by Vestas and its partners is a green process because it minimizes environmental impacts and promotes sustainability by breaking down epoxy resin into virgin-grade materials that can be reused.
product_or_process: New chemical process for breaking down epoxy resin into virgin-grade materials

title: CHEVRON PHILLIPS CHEMICAL DEEPENS COLLABORATION WITH NEXUS CIRCULAR, SECURING ... - PR Newswire
summary: Chevron Phillips Chemical (CPChem) has signed a long-term agreement with Nexus Circular to supply advanced recycled plastic feedstocks for the production of Marlex® Anew™ Circular Polyethylene. CPChem is targeting an annual production volume of 1 billion pounds of Marlex® Anew™ Circular Polyethylene by 2030.

title: New method for converting marine plastic waste into aquaculture products - RECYCLING magazine
summary: The €€Costas Project aims to reuse plastic material recovered from the sea and waste from the aquaculture industry to make products for the aquaculture industry, such as walkways, port protection products, flotation tubes, and nets and mesh for reinforcement, among other products.
